description: Leading development platform for version control, collaboration, open source contribution, and developer portfolio building
primary_use: Code repository hosting, version control (Git), collaborative development, open source projects, developer portfolios

object_details.OBJ-DEV-001: GitHub Repository - Code repository with version history, documentation, and collaboration features
object_details.OBJ-DEV-002: GitHub Profile - Developer portfolio with contributions, repos, and activity

content_types.documentation: README files, wikis, GitHub Pages sites (5%)

technical_specs.file_size_limit: 100 MB per file (with Git LFS for larger)
technical_specs.storage: Unlimited for public repos, varies for private
technical_specs.api: REST API v3, GraphQL API v4

optimal_posting.frequency: Daily commits for active projects (green contribution graph)
optimal_posting.timing: Contribute anytime (global platform, timing less critical)
optimal_posting.readme_updates: Update README.md monthly for maintained projects

best_practices: Write detailed README.md files for every project
Use meaningful commit messages (present tense, descriptive)
Create branches for features (not direct to main)
Use pull requests for code review (even solo projects)
Include LICENSE file for open source projects
Contribute to open source regularly (builds reputation)
Use GitHub Actions for CI/CD automation
Respond to issues and PRs promptly
Write clear issue descriptions with reproducible steps
Use project boards for task management
Keep commit history clean (squash when appropriate)

repository_structure.readme: Project overview, setup, usage (CRITICAL for first impression)
repository_structure.gitignore: Files to exclude from version control

github_profile_optimization.profile_readme: Create username/username repo for profile README

readme_best_practices.title_description: Clear project name and one-line description
readme_best_practices.demo: Screenshots, GIFs, or live demo links
readme_best_practices.usage: Code examples and common use cases

subject_rules: Use imperative mood (Add, not Added or Adds)

pull_request_best_practices.title: Clear, descriptive (follows commit convention)
pull_request_best_practices.description: What changed, why, how to test
pull_request_best_practices.small_prs: Focus on single feature or fix
pull_request_best_practices.ci_checks: Ensure tests pass before requesting review

open_source_contribution.fork_workflow: Fork → Clone → Branch → Commit → Push → PR
open_source_contribution.issue_first: Comment on issue before starting work

integration_opportunities: Link from Dev.to articles and tutorials
Embed repos in Stack Overflow answers
Use GitHub Pages for project documentation
Link from resume and job applications
common_use_cases: Open source project development and collaboration
Team software development and version control
Static site hosting with GitHub Pages

github_pages_strategy.setup: Enable in repo settings, choose branch
github_pages_strategy.custom_domain: Add CNAME file for custom URL
github_pages_strategy.frameworks: Support for React, Vue, Next.js, etc.

portfolio_strategy_for_developers.profile_readme: Use markdown to create visual profile
portfolio_strategy_for_developers.consistent_activity: Green contribution graph signals active developer

gitlab_better_for: Free private repos with more features

pros: Free unlimited public and private repos
Integration with countless tools and services
Strong for career building (recruiters search GitHub)
cons: Private repos have collaborator limits on free tier
GitHub Actions minutes limited on free tier
Not ideal for large binary files (without LFS)
UI can be cluttered for large projects
Merge conflicts can be complex to resolve
alternative_tools: GitLab - DevOps platform with built-in CI/CD

job_search_strategy.portfolio_readme: Visual profile with stats and skills

collaboration_workflow.fork_model: Fork → Clone → Branch → Commit → Push → PR (open source)
collaboration_workflow.shared_repo_model: Clone → Branch → Commit → Push → PR (team projects)

demographics.geographic: Global, strongest in US, Europe, Asia
demographics.professional: Individual developers, teams, enterprises, open source maintainers

github_profile_readme_ideas.blog_posts: Latest articles from dev.to or Medium

license_recommendations.MIT: Permissive, most popular for open source
license_recommendations.GPL_v3: Copyleft, requires derivatives to be open source
